text:
Sylvana Quader
Sinha is a Bangladeshi American
lawyer and entrepreneur.

In 2018, she
launched Prava Health

to address the critical
need for quality health
care in Bangladesh.

Since its founding, Prava Health
has served over half a million

patients and it's become
one of the world's

fastest growing emerging
market health care providers.

SYLVANA QUADER SINHA: I had
worked in emerging and frontier

markets for my whole career
and knew, sort of academically

and professionally,
that Bangladesh

was one of the fastest growing
economies in the world.

It struck me that despite all
of this progress, you know,

170 million people, a
middle class of 40 million,

there was no amount
of money that

could afford you access to
high quality health care.
The problem was massive.

There needed to be something
different introduced.

And so if you can really
build a brand and scale it,

there is tremendous financial
reward for that as well.

And the impact opportunity
was very clear.

As I talked to
patients, they just

didn't trust the
health care system.

Every day you have
thousands of Bangladeshis,

and every year,
billions of dollars

that were leaving the country
to access health care abroad.

Together, all of these things
presented a really compelling
opportunity to me.

So with Prava Health,
what we're trying to do

is really focus on building that
relationship between the doctor
and the patient.

This is a country where the
average amount of time doctors

spend with patients
is 48 seconds.

At Prava, we
guarantee 15 minutes.

This is also a country where,
at the time that we entered

the market, there
were literally only

four international standard
labs, for a country of 170
million people.
Today there are seven.

On a per capita basis, the
United States has 3,400 times

that level of international
standard labs.

And so patients also can't trust
that when they go to a lab,

that they're going to
get a quality result.

We have built a
lab that is set up

according to
international standards

and is, again, one of the seven
international standard labs.

I think investing
in building trust,

it's not just something that
we do because it feels good,

it's actually a
business strategy.

What we've seen over
time is by investing

in those relationships,
word of mouth marketing

has become our most
compelling touchpoint
in terms of marketing.

Our customer acquisition cost
is lower than it's ever been.

Trust is such a complex
thing, but it really

comes to earning it
one patient at a time.

You have to be based where
you're building your company.

You have to understand
your target consumer,

and there's no way to do
that sitting really far away.

For us, for example, in
Bangladesh, a lot of people
have smartphones.

Probably 100 million people have
smartphones, but some of them

might have a simplistic
version of a smartphone,

called a feature
phone, which can have
only four or five apps on it.

When we're building tools
to help with remote care

management, we have built
them for Facebook Messenger

because we don't want
our patients to have
to download a whole other app.

All of these levels
of understanding

are impossible to glean
without being on the ground.

All of my learnings taught me
that the only truly sustainable

form of development is
private sector development.

It was really important
that I built a business that

could stand the test of time and
create jobs and live on its own
beyond a charity.

80% of venture dollars
go to companies

headquartered in New York,
Massachusetts and California.

And so that's a
reality that I think

is unfortunate when
the only places

you are seeing economic growth
are in emerging markets.

Bangladesh posted
7% growth last year.

Emerging markets are still
considered by a lot of the world

as places more deserving
of charity than investment.

I can't tell you how many
investors have said to me, wow,
it's such an incredible company.

I wish I could just
make a donation.

You know, I'm just
not ready to make
an investment in Bangladesh.

I think a lot of that
is really educating

people on the opportunity
that this market presents.

It's grown faster over a longer
period of time than even China.

I think Bangladesh suffers,
to some extent, a marketing
problem.

And so a lot of my
fundraising involves
educating people on the market.
